----- Original Message -----
From: "Miles Sabin" <miles@...>
To: "rest-discuss" <rest-discuss@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Friday, April 11, 2003 6:37 AM
Subject: Re: [rest-discuss] URLs are not containers! (was Re: DELETE
container?)


> S. Alexander Jacobson wrote,
> > DELETEing a URL should simply mean that you can no longer GET or POST
> > to it.  Adding arbitrary side effects just makes it more complex to
> > interact with your application.
>
> It also has the potential to interact interestingly with DELETE's
> idempotence.
>
> FWIW, slightly related: the strawman "proof" I gave here,
>
>   http://groups.yahoo.com/group/rest-discuss/message/2349
>
> that all sequences of idempotent requests are idempotent sequences
> relies on the assumption that URIs are independent irrespective of any
> shared lexical prefix. Clearly this proof fails if that assumption is
> false.
>
> I can't remember if Walden's Alloy model made the same assumption.
> Walden?

The model I posted was extremely abstract, as you may recall,
treating "function" in the relational sense of a mapping, which we
understood to represent a state transition for some resource or
another.  There's no expressive power in a model like that for the
concept of parallel state transitions on other resources, all wrapped
up in a single operation.

In short, yes, by dint of minimal expressiveness.

Walden
